text: Yun Xiang is the mightiest champion under the Dragon Emperor. As one blessed by the Emperor, he has led the Forbidden Army of over a hundred elite soldiers, guarding the Imperial Highway for more than a century. Among Cathay’s greatest heroes, Yun Xiang’s unparalleled prowess marks him as a divine warrior.

Yun Xiang is the mightiest champion under the Dragon Emperor. As one blessed by the Emperor, he has led the Forbidden Army of over a hundred elite soldiers, guarding the Imperial Highway for more than a century. As the Emperor’s champion, Yun Xiang embodies the Emperor’s grace and wrath, slaying all who dare oppose Cathay.
Yun Xiang is the commander of the Celestial Forbidden Army, second only to the Dragons and their nine children in rank.
Gathering the finest weapons of the realm, he serves as the Emperor’s vanguard, cutting through all opposition.
The Forbidden Army consists of Cathay’s finest warriors, selected and blessed by the Dragon Emperor, transforming them into divine soldiers who crush all before them.
Beneath the high heavens, he continues to carry the blessings of the Dragon Emperor, walking as one with the divine.
As commander of the Forbidden Army, Yun Xiang also oversees key administrative duties, directly managing the Emperor’s lands in times of need.

In turbulent times, Cathay is rife with hidden threats. Some even claim it is on the brink of collapse. As the Dragon’s champion and Celestial Commander, Yun Xiang does whatever it takes to safeguard the empire, though some of the Emperor’s children view his actions as overstepping, while his power causes suspicion even in Jade Dragon Yuan Bo.

Yun Xiang is Cathay’s mightiest mortal champion, Celestial Commander, Overseer of the Two Guards, and Grand Marshal of the Forbidden Army. His presence alone inspires unwavering confidence among Cathayan soldiers.
Where can we find valiant warriors to safeguard the four corners of the empire?

The Cloud Banner General will eliminate all threats to Cathay’s grand endeavor.
The battlefield demands someone capable of rallying their forces, stabilizing Cathay’s resolve even in the direst of conflicts.
Every army of the Celestial Empire requires a strategic mind that understands its forces intimately, for only by knowing oneself can one know the enemy.
Devotion to the Lunar Rites brings serenity and longevity.
Healer of the suffering, savior of the masses.
The moon whispers dragon breath, passing its secrets to the worthy.
The Champion of the Dragon God stands here. Mortals, come forth and challenge me!
Where the gaze of the Celestial Dragon Emperor falls, only ruin awaits his foes.

From the prophecies of the Grand Celestial Bureau, Yun Xiang glimpsed his fate: the Dragon God's chosen will fall to the blade of another chosen one, yet the Celestial Palace will stand firm amid the cataclysm. 'Heaven’s Chosen' has prepared for this inevitability, for the salvation of Cathay is worth any sacrifice.
Yun Xiang, as Grand Marshal of the Celestial Guard, commands Cathay’s finest generals, with the Empire’s elite armies following his lead to vanquish all foes.
Held by the Supreme Commander of the Great Bastion, this talisman grants authority to mobilize the border armies.

The three gates have fallen, the nation lies in ruin, and the fertile lands have become desolation. Chaos gods think they have broken us, but today, we stand beneath the walls of Weijing. We are the Bastion. We are Cathay!

Guan Zimo is a celebrated heroine of Cathay, one of the few chosen by the Moon Empress. After being blessed as a member of the Wind and Cloud Orchid, she received revelations through the Veil Wind: Shang-Yang treads a precarious path, and the shadows of Chaos and destruction approach. As "Little Dragon Scales", she will act in the Moon Empress's name to aid the Eighth Lord of Shangyang and save the masses.

Guan Zimo is a celebrated heroine of Cathay and one of the Moon Empress's few chosen. Blessed as a Wind and Cloud Orchid member, she received a prophecy through the Veil Wind: Shang-Yang is on the brink of peril, and Chaos looms. As "Little Dragon Scales", she will act to aid the Eighth Lord of Shangyang and save the masses in the name of the Moon Empress.
Guan Zimo has served in Shang-Yang for over three years, known for her justice and heroism. The people rely on her deeply, calling her "Little Dragon Scales" as a hero of the sands.
When danger arises at the border, she marches a thousand miles across the rivers, driven by loyalty and courage to protect her nation and its people.
Legends of Shang-Yang tell of a lone white-robed figure appearing amidst collapsing armies, unmatched in courage and skill—a paragon of feminine strength.
Beneath the high heavens, she walks with dragons, embodying their blessing with her mortal frame.
Though Guan Zimo is but a mortal woman, her aspirations tower over mountains, and her skills level seas. A peerless heroine of her time, her will and strength rival those of dragonborn.
Endowed with divine power but driven by a heart for the people, she wields her white robes like the moonlight, cutting down Chaos and corruption in a world overrun by malevolence.
With blood-stained robes and unyielding resolve, she cuts through the storm of war.
When the flash of cold steel is seen, fear grips those who gaze upon it, for they know what follows.
Guan Zimo moves freely amidst thousands of enemies, cutting through their ranks as though they were air.
When her blade gleams, fear overtakes all who see it, for they know what comes next.

Zhao Qi's connection to nature surpasses all understanding. Some even claim to have seen her conversing with foxes, convinced she is blessed by the Moon Empress herself.

The Moonlit Order, led by Zhao Qi, spreads swiftly along Cathay’s eastern coast. Claiming to act on the Moon Empress’s visions, they promise to guide the people through the coming storm. Even the Abyss Dragon supports them, and whether their teachings are true, they are undeniably saving lives.
Zhao Qi’s forces include many volunteers from villages ravaged by Dark Elf raiders. “The Moon Empress watches over every citizen of Cathay. Stay faithful, and her protection will find you.”

Zhao Qi claims her village was destroyed by Dark Elf raiders in her youth. Rescued by the Moon Empress and raised among other orphans, she later returned to her homeland of Fuzhou as High Astronomer to bring the Empress’s blessings to her people.

It’s rare for a Dragon Prince to support a religious order within their territory, yet the Abyss Dragon has endorsed the Moonlit Order. Whether this is strategic or divine, the order now thrives in the Eastern Provinces.
Beneath the high heavens, she walks with dragons, embodying their blessing with her mortal frame.
From the Wei capital to the southern coast, Zhao Qi and her followers rescue countless lives, gathering beneath the Moonlit banner to aid Cathay.
The whispers of trees and the calls of spirits—Zhao Qi’s extraordinary bond with nature has repeatedly safeguarded Cathay’s struggling uprisings.
For Cathay’s survival, every citizen bears responsibility.
Wait, is she truly a fox?
Through sacred rituals, Zhao Qi guides the spirits of the departed back to their homelands.

Xin Qi is the descendant of the legendary Cathayan figure Xin Wu, whose martial prowess she has not only inherited but surpassed.
Loyal Servant of the Dragon Emperor

Xin Qi, descendant of the legendary Xin Wu, has inherited her ancestor’s martial valor. Initially serving under Dong Yan as a cavalry officer, her loyalty was tested when Dong rebelled. Xin Qi’s unwavering dedication and extraordinary prowess allowed her to escape deadly traps, eventually earning her the title of New Warlord.
Xin Wu is a controversial figure. Some celebrate his valor, while others decry his ruthlessness. As his descendant, Xin Qi has inherited both his martial prowess and the weight of public scrutiny.
Xin Qi owes her survival to her martial skill. Trapped in a hall surrounded by traitors, she fought her way out against impossible odds, narrowly escaping with her life.
Xin Qi’s prodigious strength enables her to wield mighty bows. Her troops, inspired by her mastery of Storm Gale, also excel in archery.
Beneath the high heavens, she walks with dragons, embodying their blessing with her mortal frame.
A lone warrior, Xin Qi can hold the line against overwhelming forces, her resolve unbroken.
Xin Qi faced betrayal twice yet remained steadfast in her loyalty, dedicating her strength to defending the Dragon Emperor.
A fiery steed crushes the enemy lines, its gallop echoing like thunder.
Arrows rain down like a storm.
Fiery arrows fly, as beautiful and deadly as their phoenix-like wielder.
The history of Cathay is graced with heroines who protect the empire as fiercely as their male counterparts.
Xin Qi’s battlefield presence is like a spirit of vengeance, daring any to challenge her.

As the most trusted mortal of the Candle Dragon and the foremost of the Twenty-Eight Constellation Generals, Duan Wei serves as the Great General of the Right for Lingnan, commanding three armies as the Marshal of the Candle Wardens.
Duke of Southern Peace Duan Wei

In times of peace in the southern provinces, the Phoenix Prayer hosted a grand banquet for the three armies, rewarding meritorious officials and establishing the Twenty-Eight General Stars. He declared: \Your loyalty is as steadfast as mountains, and together, you shine like stars. With millions under you, who can stand against us?\" Duan Wei, whose achievements were supreme, earned the highest praise, becoming the right arm of the Candle Dragon, riding with him in campaigns and seated beside him in court, and was appointed as the leader of all General Stars."
Three Triumphs of the Long Spear

Duan Wei led his forces south and cornered a major serpentmen army in the Great Serpent Rainforest. Launching a spear charge, he shattered the enemy ranks but found himself surrounded by reinforcements. Repeating this maneuver thrice, he achieved three victories, killing tens of thousands. Upon hearing of this, the Candle Dragon remarked: \"I always knew Lord Duan possessed unmatched valor, but overcoming such overwhelming odds with strategy rather than brute force is truly remarkable.\"

When ambushed by a horde of simians from all directions, Duan Wei snatched up his whips and charged forward, leaving a trail of severed heads. None could withstand his might, and the simians fled in chaos.

As the most esteemed general under the Candle Dragon, Duan Wei dominates the battlefield with unrivaled prowess. Although untested against other provincial leaders, the Candle Dragon firmly believes no mortal warrior in Cathay could surpass him. As the Grand General of the Right, Duan Wei's tactical genius and military discipline have saved countless lives.
With martial virtue, he uproots calamity and clears the murk; loyal to the Emperor, he achieves glory and shines at the heavenly gates.

For over seventy years, the Candle Wardens have stood as Cathay's exceptional defense. Although Duan Wei has led them for only a decade, he has proven to be an exceptional mortal leader, earning the trust of the Phoenix Guard and demonstrating that mortals can rival even the Dragon-Born, the Phoenix, and the gods.

The Flowfire Jade Lion, a blessed beast, strides through the southern frontier, burning away all evils.

Beyond the Heavenly Mountains, numerous beastmen tribes inspire awe among the people of Cathay. Among them, tiger-men and monkey-men, being more amenable, have established closer ties with the Cathayans and even occupy key positions within the armies of the southern provinces.

Duan Wei, the foremost general under the Candle Dragon, enjoys immense trust from the Phoenix Prayer and the acclaim of all officials. However, his arrogance and bluntness often manifest when pointing out others' mistakes. While this has garnered him numerous political enemies, it has also eradicated many chronic issues within the court.

The Han family of Nanyang, prominent nobles of Poemei descent, commanded widespread respect among aristocrats. However, during the Dragon-Born Civil War, the northern provinces were ravaged. Poemei City fell, and the leading members of noble families were executed to set an example. Han Cheng, leading his army away at the time, narrowly escaped. After the war, he was exonerated and titled Duke of Poemei. Though feared by other lords, Han Cheng proved loyal and protective of his lands for years. Yet, his rebellion and self-proclamation as King of Nanyang now evoke mixed feelings of admiration and lament.

The Han family of Nanyang, prominent nobles of Poemei descent, commanded widespread respect among aristocrats. Han Cheng, known for his military prowess, was titled Duke of Poemei. However, during the Dragon-Born Civil War, Poemei City fell, and the family was nearly wiped out. Han Cheng, away with his army, survived. Now, his rebellion and self-proclamation as King of Nanyang stir debates of vengeance and Qingbao Tianzun's manipulation.

Han Cheng’s rise began early as he inherited the rank of Captain from his father. His exceptional martial skills earned him swift promotions to General of Vigorous Might. On the battlefield, his commanding presence inspired awe and unwavering loyalty among his troops.

Cathay has stood for over ten thousand years, each generation inheriting the same lineage. Yet, the Dragon-Born are driven by personal gain, sowing discord. The war among the nine sons has left the land shattered, and my family annihilated. Qingbao Tianzun appeared to guide me, revealing the truth: Dragon-Born are not divine. Shall we continue this charade, or reclaim humanity's destiny?
Han Cheng is prepared to challenge the entire empire, even if it means standing alone.

Cathay has endured for millennia, yet the Dragon-Born squander their legacy in pursuit of personal interests. The Nine Sons' feud has left our lands devastated. My family lies in ruin, victims of their hubris. Guided by Qingbao Tianzun's wisdom, I call upon you all to restore balance and justice to our world.
As Duke of Poemei, Han Cheng commands significant military power. With the southern lords uniting under his banner, he amasses tens of thousands, sweeping across the Nine Provinces.
For the brave, the mightiest foes only stoke their courage.
The whispers of Qingbao Tianzun stir every nerve in Han Cheng's body, as accusations against the Dragon-Born replay in his mind. The myriad truths of the Dao reveal the world's hidden realities.
Han Cheng hears the voice of the Celestial Emperor, unveiling Qingbao Tianzun's schemes. The Emperor forgives his misled subjects, offering a chance to return to the path of righteousness.

During the Civil War, Han Cheng showcased unparalleled military prowess, vanquishing rebels across Yanbin Plains, Jingji Path, and Xuan Yuan. He executed the Pearl Battle by feinting east and taking the secondary capital; the Haichi Battle saw him flood rebels and Dark Elf allies, slaying 'Xuan Yuan King' Ying Qie; and in the Zhizhu Battle, his five-army formation lured and decimated 'Jade Pinnacle Lord,' forcing his suicide.

When Han Cheng marched to war, Poemei was entrusted to Dragon-Born caretakers. Despite frequent northern skirmishes, the city, nestled in Yanbin's heart and guarded by the Tianzhou Fleet, seemed secure. Yet, rebels conspired with internal traitors in blue robes to open the gates.\\n\\nThe bravest Dragon-Born were assassinated, and those involved orchestrated the massacre of loyalist officials. Prominent family heads were executed to set an example. Only generals in the industrial district escaped thanks to fleet intervention. When Han Cheng returned victorious, he found nothing but ruins.
Pools of Wine and Forests of Meat
No one in Shang-Yang could stop Ye Sheng. His army shed its facade, looting the populace while Ye Sheng and his cronies sat on their blood-stained throne.

Though the Ogre Wars had ended, bands of ogres and border tribes continued to threaten Cathay's western frontier. Ye Sheng, chosen for his political acumen, was appointed to quell the unrest. His victories in the west proved he was not merely a schemer, earning him the title General of Ogre-Slayers. Ye Sheng returned to Shang-Yang when Duke Dong Yan rebelled, joining forces with Xin Qi and Feng Yao to eliminate Dong Yan. The three swore to govern Shangyang until the Eighth Prince's return. Yet Ye Sheng's ambition led him to betray Xin Qi, seize Shangyang, and attempt to control the western provinces of Cathay.
Clearly, someone like Ye Sheng would stop at nothing to ensure his survival.
Though Ye Sheng seized Shang-Yang during a power vacuum, Zhao Ming will eventually return. We cannot hope to defeat the Dragon himself. But at least, we have friends waiting to make their move...
Shang-Yang is Ye Sheng's miniature Cathay, and his enforcers ensure his terrifying control permeates every corner.

Once a person's moral boundaries are broken, there is no bottom to their depravity. Ye Sheng's path to power is drenched in blood and schemes. His infiltration into Shang-Yang's structure runs so deep that even the Holy Ministry's overseers have become his personal assassins. Until Zhao Ming and his wrath arrive, no one can stop Ye Sheng's growing ambition.
Burn it! Take their wealth and manpower, then turn this worthless city and its people to ash. Let others witness the price of opposing me!
Ye Sheng's network of spies blankets Shang-Yang, ensuring any opposition disappears without a trace.
Ye Sheng never worries about supplies. As long as there are people, there are resources to exploit.

No one knows the origin of the Jade Blood Curse, but this nightmare has plagued the once-prosperous Nongchang Basin for ages. Most survivors have fled, but some, like Jin Xiao and the Jade Guard, continue to fight for their homeland.

When the Jade Blood curse descended upon the Nongchang Basin, Protector-General Jin Xiao was ensnared in the nightmare of undeath. His unyielding will, extraordinary physique, or sheer luck preserved his full consciousness, even in his skeletal state. Donning the Protector-General's mask, Jin Xiao led Nongchang's survivors against the Jade Blood tribes. With the arrival of Jade Dragon, Nongchang's crisis was temporarily resolved, but Jin Xiao's secret was uncovered. To Jin Xiao's surprise, Yuan Bo used powerful magic to transform his decayed form into jade. This new, energized body surpassed his mortal capabilities. Although Yuan Bo soon departed, leaving his motives unclear, Jin Xiao vowed to make the most of his second chance.
Technically, Jin Xiao has been dead for a long time. Yet his jade bones have given him a vitality and strength beyond anything he knew in life.

Jin Xiao has fought the Jade Blood tribes longer than anyone else. While others succumbed to undeath or were buried beneath the soil, Jin Xiao's curse became his foundation for resistance. With Yuan Bo's blessing, he wields an unstoppable force to unleash the people's wrath upon the Jade Blood tribes.
After countless battles, Jin Xiao regards life and death lightly, his blade cutting through clouds and laying jade upon the sand.

The once-prosperous Nongchang lies in ruins. While the Jade Guard struggles to hold the capital, Jin Xiao knows they must reclaim their homeland quickly. If the survivors lose hope within their crumbling walls, they will fall before the endless Jade Blood horde.
Golden Lance Commander Qin Yuan Yi

The Southern Ridge is among the most perilous regions of Cathay, where endless assaults ravage the garrisons. Despite the odds, some emerge as shining stars among the fallen, becoming the empire's last line of defense.

The Qin clan of the Southern Ridge is the most influential family south of Shengjiang and a pillar of support for Li Dao's rule. Qin Yuan Yi's father, Qin Wen Cheng, was a renowned statesman, while Yuan Yi has become a distinguished general in Li Dao's service.
Unorthodox tactics break enemies across vast distances.

The Qin clan of the Southern Ridge is the most influential family south of Shengjiang and a pillar of support for Li Dao's rule. Qin Wen Cheng, Yuan Yi's father, was a prominent statesman, and Yuan Yi is now one of Li Dao's most celebrated generals.
It is believed that Qin Yuan Yi's soul contains the essence of a Celestial Beast, ready to manifest in dire moments.

The Qin clan of the Southern Ridge is the most influential family south of Shengjiang and a pillar of support for Li Dao's rule. Qin Wen Cheng, Yuan Yi's father, was a prominent statesman, and Yuan Yi is now one of Li Dao's most celebrated generals.

Qin Yuan Yi's unparalleled strength and Zhu Lance make him a fearsome warrior. In the Bamboo Grove Crossing, he single-handedly held back the rebel forces, slaying their leader and fending off three formidable adversaries without faltering.
It is believed that Qin Yuanyi's soul harbors the essence of a divine beast of Cathay, and in critical moments, this power will manifest to protect him.
Qin Yuanyi and Duan Wei each guard one end of the Grand Canal, serving as the guardian deities of Cathay, protecting its people from the threats lurking beyond.

The essence of the divine beast is an unbearable burden for mortals, a weight that should have claimed Qin Yuanyi's life long ago. Yet, he has survived this struggle against fate, mastering its power as his own.

In different regions, the stories of Hou Qian vary greatly. In northern ballads, he is depicted as a bloodthirsty and violent giant ape. In western tales, he is a baboon-like creature with golden fur and a red, swollen backside—traits attributed to his unyielding fury. Along the eastern coasts, he is a gargantuan gorilla with a monstrous appetite and a belly covered in ugly boils. In the southern narratives, the Monkey King is a small spider monkey, leaping across the shoulders of friends and foes alike, his words a blend of truth and deception.
The Warden of the Heavenly Gate Hou Qian
The Warden of the Heavenly Gate

As the Warden of the Heavenly Gate, Hou Qian commands the ten thousand Dragon Guards of Weijing. He is Yuanbo's most trusted Dragon-blooded and a favorite general of Yunxiang. His deft mediation ensures a precarious balance between the two.

Above the Celestial Court, the Dragon Emperor's Imperial Guard stands vigilant around the Palace of the Celestial Heaven, their leader the sole envoy to the Shen Ce Bureau. Following the Battle of Po Mei, the Imperial Guard withdrew their defensive boundary, transferring the protection of Weijing's walls to mortal hands. The newly assembled Tian Ting Dragon Guard, based in the capital, became a formidable force. Hou Qian, once one among many Dragon-blooded, rose to prominence through repeated victories, eventually becoming the Guardian of Weijing and leader of ten thousand guards.

Cathay is a land brimming with the winds of magic, imbuing all things with spiritual energy. Some of these entities evolve into malicious spirits that plague the land. Most such threats are managed by local officials or monks, but at times, greater monsters arise, demanding intervention from the Shen Ce Bureau. In such cases, Hou Qian leads the Heavenly Court's forces to subdue these demonic threats.

Like Longma and Qilin, the Jiaolong (Dragon-Serpent) are an ancient lineage of dragons. Despite their similarities to the Dragonkin, their uncontrollable rage rendered them outcasts, banished to the depths of lakes and abysses. While some found purpose as guardians, others succumbed to bitterness, transforming into monstrous entities that unleashed fury and floods upon the land. Hou Qian's homeland bears a stone tablet inscribed with the tale: "The Jiaolong emerged with each flood, wreaking havoc and claiming lives. None could stand against it until Qian took his blade and confronted the beast in its lair, emerging victorious and bringing peace to the land."

Born with a celestial eye, Hou Qian can pierce through illusions and discern the true essence of things. When a shape-shifting spirit attempted to infiltrate the Shen Ce Bureau disguised as Yunxiang, it was Hou Qian who unmasked the deception with a single glance.

After the Monkey King was defeated and fled south, Hou Qian was ordered by Yunxiang to lead 50,000 troops from the capital and join the allied dragons in pursuit. Hou Qian, using cloud-walking techniques, advanced alone and intercepted the Monkey King at Kunlan Mountain. If the Monkey King had fought as he did during the Heavenly Court battle, chaos would have ensued. But with no time to spare, the Monkey King could only respond hastily. Hou Qian's exceptional martial prowess overwhelmed the Monkey King, with the gleaming Three-Pointed, Double-Edged Blade forcing him on the defensive. Yet, the Monkey King's divine abilities and myriad tricks left Hou Qian astonished. When the situation grew dire, Hou Qian retrieved a celestial axe gifted by the Elder of Kunshan and struck at the Monkey King. The Monkey King dodged, leaving only scattered fur as he vanished, and the celestial axe split the mountains, creating a great chasm.
From one to ten, ten to a hundred, and hundreds to countless transformations—all are the powers of the Howling Skyhound.

A hundred years have passed since that day, and Xinwu lies desolate, its ruins swept by aimless winds of yellow sand. Bold merchants passing through tell tales of vibrant activity in the ruins, though their vision is obscured by the Yellow Wind. Whether it is man or monster remains unknown.

A century has passed since that fateful day. Xinwu is now deserted, its lands ravaged by aimless yellow sands. Bold merchants passing through whisper of bustling activity in the ruins, yet the Yellow Wind obscures their vision. Man or monster, no one can say for sure.
The myriad mystical arts of the Elder of Kunlan, now mastered by this monstrous being. What a travesty! One wonders what the Elder must think of this calamity from the heavens above...

The Yellow Wind Great Sage claimed Xinwu for itself, wielding immense power. With the head of Xinwu's general forged into an artifact, it became an unchallenged overlord, drawing chaotic spirits and fiends from all directions to swear allegiance.

In the days of old, the winds of Xinwu wreaked havoc so great that Miao Ying lost her White Tiger and Zao Ming fled with the Black Tortoise. The Nine Provinces and Three Realms trembled, and even the Monkey King, when ascending to the Celestial Court, warned his kin to steer far from this cursed place.

Legend has it the Yellow Wind Great Sage stole the head of Xinwu's great general to absorb the essence of heaven and earth. Yet, enlightenment eluded it, driving it to rage. Its fury razed Xinwu to the ground, and for another hundred years, it roamed maddened and malevolent.

After Xinwu's catastrophic winds, the Celestial Court repeatedly sent armies to quell the Yellow Wind Great Sage. Mighty as it was, it matched Cathay's celestial forces blow for blow, supported by formidable generals and warriors. The blinding Yellow Wind Array ensured Cathay's armies often returned empty-handed.

Yinjiangzi Xue Ding is the Left Guardian General of the Jade Court. He accompanied Yunfengzi in the campaign against Lustria, clad in a white robe, holding a staff and suspended talismans, charging into battle with a thunderous cry, unstoppable. Xue Ding has fought alongside the Jade Dragon for over two decades, defeating nine tribes of savage Beastmen, subjugating the Black Lotus Vampires, and crushing the Lizardmen, earning great renown.
Xue Ding plays a pivotal role in Cathay's foreign wars, appearing in almost every campaign. Countless enemies who underestimated Cathay have knelt under his conquests.
Ding followed the Jade Dragon in campaigns for over twenty years, vanquishing the Nine Tribes of savage Orcs, subduing the Black Lotus Bloodline, and defeating the Lizardmen, earning great merit.
Xue Ding's renown spreads far and wide. He was bestowed the rank of Yunhui Commander and instructor of Cathay's Thirty-Six Military Academies by Yuan Bo.
Xue Ding not only campaigns abroad but also ensures domestic stability. His jurisdiction is orderly and thriving, with well-prepared troops ready to serve the Jade Dragon's needs.
The Might of the Jade Court

Xue Ding is the Left Protector General of the Jade Court. When he fights abroad, his glory is the Jade Court's glory, and his strength is the Jade Court's strength.\\n\\nHe will never bring shame upon the Jade Court.
Xue Ding leads the Left Army of the Jade Court, with tens of thousands of soldiers at his command. He has taken this legion across the four seas.

Liu Yue Ru is the direct disciple of the "Xuan Maiden" of the Xuanzhen Sect in Fuzhou. After the Battle of Xuan Yuan, most sect leaders perished. Though the "Xuan Maiden" survived, she was severely injured and beyond recovery. Liu Yue Ru and her sisters fought valiantly, but out of 800 disciples, only seven survived. With the sect in ruins, the "Xuan Maiden" passed the sword techniques to Liu Yue Ru to ensure the Xuanzhen Sect's legacy would not vanish from the world. The "Xuan Maiden" was buried in Hengshan, Fuzhou, and the sisters scattered—some dying in battles against the Dark Elves, others retreating from the martial world. Now, only Liu Yue Ru remains, leaving the empty mountain gates behind, wandering the world to assassinate Dark Elf nobles. Her past is but a fleeting tale; now the world only remembers the name of the Heartless Sword.

Liu Yue Ru is the personal disciple of the Xuan Nu sect in Fuzhou’s Xuan Heng school. After the Battle of Xuan Yuan, most of the sect leaders perished. Although the Xuan Nu survived, she was gravely injured and beyond salvation. Liu Yue Ru and her sisters fought valiantly, yet only seven of the 800 disciples survived. With the sect in such dire straits, the Xuan Nu passed on the Xuan Heng sword techniques to Liu Yue Ru, determined not to let their legacy die. The Xuan Nu was laid to rest in Heng Mountain, Fuzhou, and her sisters scattered—some falling in battles against the Dark Elves, others retreating from the world. Liu Yue Ru, now alone, wanders the land, assassinating high-ranking Dark Elves. Her past is a mere tale, but the name "Heartless Sword" remains in legend.
Liu Yue Ru is the personal disciple of the Xuan Nu and inherited the Xuan Heng sword techniques during a time of crisis, carrying the hundred-year legacy of the Xuan Heng school on her shoulders.

At the Martial Alliance conference, many sects prided themselves on being upright and reputable. However, during the nation's crisis, most hesitated. The Xuan Heng sect was the first to support Tang Jing Yin. True heroes cannot stand idly by while Dark Elves wreak havoc. If one claims to follow the way of chivalry, they must act in the world's darkest hour.
Seven hundred and ninety-three disciples of the Xuan Heng sect perished in a single day. The blood debt owed by the Dark Elves must be repaid a hundredfold.
The tragedies of the past must never be repeated. As long as I draw breath, I will ensure they never will.

In her final moments, the Xuan Nu entrusted the Xuan Heng sword technique to Liu Yue Ru. Unlike the domineering Hou Suan blade style or the sharp Yufeng swordsmanship, the Xuan Heng sword technique is ever-changing, fluid in its offense and defense.\\n\\n[[col:green]]The profound Xuan Heng sword technique remains elusive to Liu Yue Ru, and additional skill points can be invested to further master the technique and gain corresponding attribute bonuses.[[/col]]
Her sect has vanished along with its members. Liu Yue Ru is the last surviving disciple of the Xuan Heng school.

One of the three stars of Xingpo, Ku Xi has attained a profound level of mastery. Alternating between human and raven form, their true nature is shrouded in mystery. Initially feared by the alchemists, Ku Xi proved loyal to the nation, commanding the Raven Feathers in service to the Moon Empress and earning acclaim for defending the land. The Celestial Bureau regards Ku Xi as a cornerstone of their forces.
You hear the rustle of feathers and feel the blade closing in, but where is he?

The rumors among surviving strategists grow increasingly exaggerated. They claim the Raven Guard killed 18 royal guards with a single feather. Was it truly a feather, or a sword disguised as one? The dying will never know.

Many conspiracists among Cathay’s elite believe the Raven Guard collaborates with Skaven infiltrators, citing the frequent appearance of Skaven assassins where the Raven Guard is active. They fail to consider that it may be the Raven Guard’s presence that reveals these elusive foes.
Ku Xi, the leader and mentor of the Raven Guard in Xingpo’s forbidden army, is a terror in the hearts of all who oppose Cathay.
None dare claim to know if Ku Xi is man or raven, but all who meet him on the battlefield hear the haunting cries of terror around him.
No matter the treachery, this blade will strike them all down.
As the founder of the Raven Guard, Ku Xi’s unparalleled skills have solidified his status as Cathay’s master assassin.
The Raven Guard serves the Moon Empress, excelling in stealth and assassination far beyond the Hongwu Inspectors of the imperial court. Every Raven Guard member was trained by Ku Xi.
The Raven Guard’s eyes see all...
Those marked by them are as good as dead...
Your nightmare has come to life...

As precise as spirits, as swift as thunder. Advancing is unstoppable, retreating is elusive. Fore and rear coordinate, left and right command. Harnessing the nature of the five elements, altering the laws of the four seasons. Is he mortal or immortal? I cannot tell; he shines with celestial clarity.
Open, Rest, Life, Harm, Obstruction, Scene, Death, Shock. When the Eight Trigrams are deployed, the enemy is decisively defeated.
A creation of the Celestial Court, it is a scaled-down replica of the majestic structures in Wei-Jin.
A general’s warhorse is both their most trusted and courageous companion. Just don’t name it "Little Daisy."
Fang Wenzi possesses unparalleled talent, wielding the energies of the essence wind with extraordinary skill. However, his body has become fragile from bearing such otherworldly power.

Fang Wenzi is a high-ranking Astral Overseer of the Celestial Bureau and one of Xingpo’s Three Stars. Guided by the Dragon Emperor and Moon Empress in their secret plans, mortals like Fang Wenzi are inspired to take critical actions to prevent Cathay from falling into calamity. He is now the chosen representative of the Moon Empress.

Fang Wenzi, a high-ranking Astral Overseer of the Celestial Bureau, serves as the voice of the Moon Empress. Guided by their secret plans, he is inspired to take critical actions to avert disaster and preserve Cathay's future.
Although a senior member of the Astral Overseers, Fang Wenzi prefers the wilderness, where he communes with the world's spirit and hones his inner clarity.
Fang Wenzi plans meticulously, considering every detail. In military affairs, each step is calculated ten steps ahead.

During the Monkey King's rebellion, Fang Wenzi, guided by the Moon Empress, represented the Jade Dragon Court. He negotiated with the Dragon Princes, outmaneuvering opponents in debate and uniting them to fight the rebels. His strategies and eloquence were unparalleled.
Fang Wenzi’s compiled chronicles serve as vital references for the administration of the Celestial Empire, documenting every detail comprehensively.
Through a series of reforms, Fang Wenzi weakened the hold of local magnates on the lower economy, alleviating corruption-induced stagnation.
Preparing for all contingencies before a campaign ensures calm amidst crisis.
Every strike, every breath, every punch, and every technique is etched into the surging blood of Pei Yue.

Smiling at the gritted teeth of the world, raising another cup of wine, striking the heavens with torrential fists, we ascend the azure clouds with bold spirits.                                                             [[col:green]]The base attributes of the Martial Obsessive increase with level. At level 50, Pei Yue's four main attributes gain a 20% bonus.[[/col]]
When Pei Yue holds his breath and focuses his energy, even the surrounding waters calm under his pressure. He redirects the enemy's force with internal energy and returns it with interest.

Pei Yue has ascended to the pinnacle of martial arts. Every hero in Cathay has fallen to his fists, and among the mountains, no rival remains. Having experienced so much, the Martial Obsessive may now understand martial arts and heroism better than those who claim to be paragons.
Pei Yue’s martial path, unlike most of Cathay’s heroes, holds no deeper meaning. Martial arts are purely martial arts. Following this path, he has reached perfection.
Pei Yue's fist techniques are so pure that few masters of Cathay's countless styles can last even one bout against him.

Pei Yue’s life has been an unending journey. He has traversed every corner of Cathay, defeating arrogant martial masters of one sect after another in pursuit of martial perfection. Now, the Martial Obsessive serves under the Binlong Gate, ready to sweep aside the champions of Shang-Yang.

Pei Yue’s life has been an unending journey. He has traversed every corner of Cathay, defeating arrogant martial masters of one sect after another in pursuit of martial perfection. Now, the Martial Obsessive serves under the Binlong Gate, ready to sweep aside the champions of Shang-Yang.
Those northern warriors who pride themselves on being born for battle charge forward, only to fall beneath his fists.
On the southern shores of Yujian, where martial arts flourish, no one can withstand the Martial Obsessive’s strike.
Even in Shang-Yang, where champions from across the lands gather, Pei Yue easily claims the title of champion.

The "Martial Saint" has traversed the vast history of Cathay for centuries. As a general of the New Martial era and the Jade Dragon's chosen champion, he was granted divine artifacts and the same extended lifespan as the Dragon Emperor's Forbidden Army. Tasked with protecting Cathay's peace alongside the dragons, the soldiers who once fought with him have long since perished. Modern citizens no longer recall his true name, but the title "Martial Saint" remains etched in history.

The "Martial Saint" has safeguarded Cathay for a century, adorned with the Emperor's bestowed jade mask. Legends among the people revere him as a divine protector, a figure that strikes terror into the hearts of traitors and malicious spirits alike.
Already unparalleled, the "Martial Saint" has grown even stronger through centuries of battle.
The title "Martial Saint" has become synonymous with the highest virtues of a warrior in the hearts of Cathay’s people. Many revere him as a divine protector, the Jade-Carved Sovereign.
The soldiers who once fought alongside him have passed into history. Alone, the "Martial Saint" now defends the nation's gates, steadfast against any foe.
The "Martial Saint" removes the restrictions of his mask, allowing his suspended life force to flow once more.
An era of peace faces new chaos and suffering. As harmony flows, righteous warriors rise to restore order and quell rebellion.
Blade in hand, horse at the ready, wine warming the soul—he charges through the enemy ranks with unparalleled strength.

Ying Jin, a renowned prodigy of Nanyang since childhood, only grew more dazzling with age. After entering government service under the enigmatic Po Mei, Ying Jin has dutifully assisted his lord in all matters, earning universal respect throughout the court.
Ying Jin, known as the "Precious Jade Gentleman," is a globally renowned scholar and an unparalleled statesman.

Ying Jin has been celebrated as a prodigy in Nanyang since childhood, and his unstoppable brilliance has only grown with age. After entering the service of Po Mei, Ying Jin personally managed all affairs, earning the unwavering respect of the court.

Po Mei's Heavenly Fleet technology is world-renowned, rivaling even the craftsmen of Nangao. These powerful war machines are a cornerstone of Po Mei's military, and under Ying Jin's command, they have never known defeat.

Despite decades of friendship between Han Cheng and Ying Jin, they found themselves irreconcilably divided over the issue of rebellion. Ying Jin tried tirelessly to persuade Han Cheng to see the hidden conspiracies behind the uprising, but another force seemed to cloud his friend's judgment. Though Ying Jin failed, he did not abandon his bewitched comrade. Retreating from public life, Ying Jin resolved to save Han Cheng before the situation became irreparable. Should all else fail, Ying Jin would take up arms against the rebel king of Nanyang for Cathay’s greater good.
At Ying Jin's command, a rain of fire descends from the skies, obscuring the sun and covering the battlefield in flames.
Fires blaze across the heavens, illuminating the seas of clouds, reducing masts and sails to ash.
Ying Jin commands the Heavenly Fleet with his flute, each melody carrying an order.
Who can understand the warrior's heart through his flute, as it plays over the sands where bones lie beneath the moon?

Po Mei’s craftsmen relentlessly pursue advancements in Heavenly Fleet technology, striving to outpace their rivals in Nangao and the Wujian Guild. Their innovations are fully implemented in Ying Jin's fleet.

Yi Yaohua, elder sister of Yi Qing the "Heavenly Defeater of Barbarians," earned great acclaim during the Third Northern Expedition. She now serves as the distinguished Grand Minister of the Jade Court, acting as a bridge between the Jade Dragons and mortals, as well as a messenger between the Celestial Court and the Jade Dragons.

Yi Yaohua, elder sister of Yi Qing the "Heavenly Defeater of Barbarians," earned great acclaim during the Third Northern Expedition. She now serves as the distinguished Grand Minister of the Jade Court, acting as a bridge between the Jade Dragons and mortals, as well as a messenger between the Celestial Court and the Jade Dragons.

She now serves as the distinguished Grand Minister of the Jade Court, acting as a bridge between the Jade Dragons and mortals, as well as a messenger between the Celestial Court and the Jade Dragons.
Every Grand Minister is celebrated by the people, their presence seen as a sign of the Dragon Emperor and Moon Empress's favor for the region.
Yi Yaohua recites blessings during rituals to convey the wishes of mortals to the Heavenly Dragon.

The southern regions of Cathay are steeped in shamanistic culture, tracing back to the Dragon Emperor's first arrival. The locals believe these ancient rituals can avert disasters and repel evil spirits, while some even use them to harm enemies.

The people of Cathay revere the concept of celestial-human resonance. Various forms of rituals are held to seek blessings from the Heavenly Dragon Emperor, and conducting these ceremonies is the duty of the Grand Ministers.
Deputy Commander of the Forbidden Army

Miao Yi, the deputy commander under Yun Xiang, is the only known female member of the Dragon Emperor's Forbidden Army. While most legendary heroines of Cathay are chosen for the Moon Empress's court, a celestial envoy summoned Miao Yi by the Heavenly Dragon's name, granting her the Dragon Emperor's blessing. For a century after the Heavenly Dragon's departure, the Forbidden Army has fought and sacrificed countless times to safeguard Cathay. Today, fewer than a hundred remain, but Miao Yi and her comrades steadfastly uphold their ancient oaths, for this autumn and all eternity.
Deputy Commander of the Forbidden Army

Miao Yi, deputy commander under Yun Xiang, is the only known female member of the Dragon Emperor's Forbidden Army. While most legendary heroines of Cathay are selected for the Moon Empress's court, a celestial envoy summoned Miao Yi by the name of the Heavenly Dragon, granting her the Dragon Emperor's blessing. Over a century since the Heavenly Dragon's departure, the Forbidden Army has fought countless battles, sacrificing much to protect Cathay. Today, fewer than a hundred remain, yet Miao Yi and her comrades continue to uphold their ancient oaths, steadfast through the ages.

Miao Yi, deputy commander under Yun Xiang, is the only known female member of the Dragon Emperor's Forbidden Army. She was summoned by a celestial envoy under the Heavenly Dragon's name, becoming one of the last to receive the Dragon Emperor's blessing. Over a century of battle has worn down the Forbidden Army, yet Miao Yi and her comrades persist, dedicated to their ancient vows.

To the mortal realm, the Dragon Emperor's Forbidden Army is the stuff of legend. In the time of the Dragon Emperor, they were an unstoppable force capable of conquering any land. However, as the Emperor and Moon Empress turned their focus to their grand plans, external threats surged. The Forbidden Army, unable to replenish its numbers, became a rarity. Though few remain today, their arrival on the battlefield reminds Cathay's people of the overlap between myth and reality.

The last time the Great Bastion fell, an unprecedented Chaos horde surged into Cathay. Clay colossi crumbled in the Terracotta Graveyard, Po Mei burned as its Heavenly Fleet fell, and Yuan Bo’s Jade Legion was misled into the mists by Tzeentch's schemes. In Cathay's darkest hour, the Forbidden Army held the Chaos horde at Po Mei, banishing nine Greater Daemons and scattering the remnants of the Chaos forces. Yet the losses were devastating, marking the end of the Forbidden Army’s era as Cathay's ultimate safeguard.

After the last great war, the Forbidden Army rarely left the capital—until civil war erupted. Sent across Cathay to strip generals of their power, they crushed any disobedience with brutal efficiency. The rebellion was suppressed, but mistrust between the Forbidden Army and Yuan Bo deepened. Miao Yi was dispatched by Yun Xiang to seek aid from the Celestial Court, but Yuan Bo, focused on his mission, declined their request, sowing seeds of discord that would later fuel conflict within the court.

Though endless warfare has eroded the emotions of the Forbidden Army, Miao Yi developed a unique bond with Yun Xiang. Her duties weigh heavily on her, leaving little time for reflection, yet she knows that, if needed, she would gladly give her life for him.

The Celestial Strategy Bureau was deeply infiltrated by disciples of Tzeentch, even resulting in high-ranking officials being impersonated. Miao Yi, under Yun Xiang's orders, led numerous investigations into the Bureau, enlisting the assistance of the Celestial Raven Guard to purge Chaos corruption from the capital.
Deputy Commander of the Forbidden Army

During the last Dark Elf invasion, Tang Jingyin united martial sects across Cathay as the Wulin Alliance Leader, leading them to a Pyrrhic victory at the Great Bastion. Countless heroes, including his wife, sacrificed their lives. Tang Jingyin vanished after the battle. With Cathay in peril once more, he emerges from the shadows.

During Tang Jingyin's era, many of the greatest warriors perished in the Battle of the Great Bastion. When the imperial forces were stretched thin, it was these vigilante heroes, often distrusted by the authorities, who stood in defense of Cathay's vulnerable flank. After the battle, the Celestial Court posthumously honored the fallen heroes with official titles, and Tang Jingyin, the Wulin Alliance Leader, was granted the title "Duke of the Bastion". However, to those who fought alongside him and under his protection, he is remembered simply as the "Grand Hero".

Tang Jingyin’s time has passed, yet he vividly remembers the horrors of the Great Bastion. As the Dark Elves exploited the long coastline, the Celestial forces were consumed by Chaos incursions from the north and south. Under Yuan Bo's guidance, the Celestial Court reluctantly convened the Wulin Assembly, gathering the era's martial heroes. After defeating his peers in combat and delivering a resounding speech, Tang Jingyin united the disparate factions, convincing them to march toward a battlefield many would not return from.
The Seven Techniques of Yin Jing
Yin Jing did not belong to any specific sect but developed his martial art that integrated techniques across disciplines, forming a style unmatched under the heavens.

In the Battle of the Great Bastion, Tang Jingyin lost his wife and comrades. Even after driving back the final wave of Dark Elves while grievously wounded, he found only corpses among the battlefield. Consumed by despair, he cast himself into the Jade River, intending to end his life, but was rescued by a Dragon Monk. Tang Jingyin then withdrew from the world, hiding in the mountains for over a decade.

For years, Cathay enjoyed peace after the battle, but ominous portents foretold its end. The Dark Elves returned, the Blood of Jade ravaged the land, Kurgan horsemen trampled the borders, and Serpentfolk hissed in the southern jungles. Though burdened by past sorrows, Tang Jingyin knew he could not turn away from Cathay’s plight. So, at this moment of peril, the "Grand Hero" returned.

Though the Dragon Emperor is said to have secluded himself in the Celestial Tower for a century, forsaking the mortal realm, some believe his gaze still falls upon his people. Tang Jingyin, seeking to repay the kindness of the Dragon Monks who saved him, ventured to the Hall of Heaven surrounded by the Blood of Jade. On the brink of death, he was granted a divine miracle: the winds of Qi coursed through his body, manifesting a spectral arm imbued with newfound strength. Alone against the horde, he realized the Dragon Emperor had not abandoned his people.

Tang Jingyin's return was inevitable. Once more, he took up the mantle of a hero, aiding the innocent and rescuing the endangered. News of his return spread quickly, drawing old comrades and aspiring warriors eager to see him restored as the Wulin Alliance Leader. Yet, not all welcomed him. Some questioned his survival and doubted the heroism of his actions, believing a hero’s sacrifice defined them. Despite these doubts, Tang Jingyin resolved to uphold the true essence of chivalry.
Drunken yet resolute, overturning seas and clouds with indomitable spirit.
Immutable in chaos, serene in spirit.
Rising to the azure heavens, soaring on boundless winds, transcending all.

Legends of the Monkey King vary across Cathay. In the north, he is depicted as a bloodthirsty gorilla. To western storytellers, he is a baboon with golden fur and swollen features, perpetually enraged. On the eastern coasts, he is described as a gluttonous ape with a grotesque belly. In the south, he is seen as a nimble gibbon, darting between shoulders, his words a mix of truth and lies.

Legends of the Monkey King vary greatly across regions. In the north, he is described in ballads as a bloodthirsty and savage gorilla. Western storytellers portray him as a baboon with golden fur and swollen features, always angry. On the eastern coast, he is a massive ape with an insatiable appetite and a belly covered in grotesque boils. In the south, he is a nimble spider monkey, leaping on the shoulders of allies and enemies alike, speaking truths and lies in equal measure.

The monkeys of the Simian Court sing endlessly of the Monkey King: it is said that long before the Dragon Emperor's arrival, a celestial stone stood atop the Tianshan Mountains. One day, the stone split open, giving birth to a stone egg. When the wind touched it, it transformed into a stone monkey. As it opened its eyes, beams of divine light shot into the heavens, startling even the Dragon Emperor in the Celestial Court miles away. This stone monkey became the Monkey King.

For years, the Monkey King reveled in carefree joy on the Tianshan Mountains. Seeking immortality, he wandered the world, apprenticing under various masters. Though his unparalleled talent allowed him to learn many strange arts, his mischievous nature often got him expelled for showing off.

In Imperial Year 2377, the Monkey King seized power over Cathay. He appointed Tretch Craventail of Clan Eshin as an advisor to establish trade with Skaven clans. Eventually, the dragons realized that they must unite to face this self-proclaimed ruler.

Calling the Simian Court a "court" is perhaps a stretch, as the Monkey King and his followers rarely adhere to decorum. Still, many expect him to govern his monkey warriors as the dragons rule Cathay's people. But the court's meetings invariably descend into chaos. While the Monkey King boasts that his rule rivals that of any dragon scion, others can only marvel at the disorder he has wrought.

After the battle at the Celestial Court, the Monkey King barely escaped the dragon scions' pursuit, retreating to Tianshan. But the Dragon Emperor’s gaze was inescapable: the Five Elements Compass roared, reshaping Tianshan’s landscape. Amidst the dust and chaos, the Monkey King found himself trapped within the mountain’s rocky embrace. The Dragon Emperor’s voice resonated in his mind, explaining that while the Monkey King had not caused irreparable harm, his mischief had disrupted Cathay’s harmony, creating opportunities for greater evils. This punishment was also a chance: one day, travelers would pass through Tianshan, and the Monkey King’s shackles would be broken, signaling the beginning of his true mission.

Amid chaos, the Monkey King's troops stormed Weijing, with the king himself reaching the Celestial Court. The once-proud champions guarding the Dragon Emperor’s palace were outwitted and humiliated. Even the legendary Yunxiang, the Emperor's mightiest champion, was at a loss. The Monkey King fled only when the united dragon forces approached the capital.
Divide into ten, into hundreds, into thousands. Infinite transformations of self: this is the Cloning Technique.
By consuming celestial peaches, imperial wine, and dragon elixirs, the Monkey King forged his body in the Samadhi Fire, rendering it impervious to blades, flames, toxins, and lightning.

Though the Monkey King learned immortality from the Tianshan Patriarch, he could only achieve eternal life by evading the "Three Calamities." After much pleading, the Patriarch taught him the Seventy-Two Transformations, allowing him to evade heavenly lightning, underworld fire, and raging winds.
To take form and dissipate, leaving no trace.
Through mystic arts, a single pointed finger roots the enemy in place, unable to move.

Nezha was once the third prince of Zhulong's court, a pureblood descendant of Zhulong known for his rebellious nature. Though adored by Zhulong, his insolence caused a grave incident when he accidentally killed a delegate’s scion during a dispute. Knowing the calamity he caused, Nezha sacrificed himself to protect Lingnan. Mourning his loss, Zhulong sent his remains to Kunlan, where the Kunlan Elder performed a lotus reincarnation ritual to preserve Nezha’s soul. He now serves as an attendant to the Elder, seeking redemption.
Nezha's mortal body perished a century ago, leaving behind a vessel crafted by the Kunlan Elder through divine methods. This incarnation possesses immortal, boundless abilities.
As a pureblood descendant of Zhulong, Nezha inherited unmatched abilities and shared a similar temperament to Zhulong, earning him the title of "Third Prince of Lingnan."

While living as a prince, Nezha’s defiant nature brought calamity. Angered by the arrogance of the Moondragon's emissaries toward commoners, he humiliated them until a conflict erupted. In his wrath, Nezha flayed a dragon scion by the canal, only realizing too late the gravity of his actions.

Filled with remorse, Nezha staggered back to Zhulong's court, only to find it besieged by Moondragon forces seeking vengeance. To protect Zhulong's court, Nezha drew his blade and slit his throat. His lifeblood, ignited by his celestial sash, dissipated alongside his life.

Zhulong, grieving for his son, sought a way to revive him. Neither the Phoenix Mother's sacred temple nor the Tianshan Patriarch's potions could restore his essence. Turning to Kunlan, the Elder, blessed by the Dragon Emperor, used a lotus rebirth technique to create an incarnation for Nezha. He infused it with spiritual energy to summon Nezha’s soul, binding it to the new vessel. On the eve of Nezha’s return, Zhulong departed, leaving the Elder to guide Nezha as his disciple and to redeem his past sins.

Since his revival, Nezha abandoned his princely title and never returned to Lingnan or Zhulong. As a devoted student under the Kunlan Elder, he trained diligently for a century. After the Elder's passing, Nezha joined the Celestial Court, fighting tirelessly. Though his penance may now be complete, one day, he hopes to see his homeland again.

After a century of training atop Kunlan, Nezha descended during the outbreak of civil war. Serving as an opening vanguard, Nezha's fiery demeanor struck awe in all who witnessed his feats, as his identity remained hidden.
To divide one into ten, ten into a hundred, a hundred into countless forms—this is the Way of Many Bodies.

Their power shakes the eight directions, sweeping through the remnants of clouds.
Formidable in battle, they lead the charge.
The supreme martial skills of the Cloud Banner Commanders inspire the soldiers under them.
Cloud Banner Commanders possess the bravery to hold a pass alone against countless foes, facing danger with unyielding resolve.

Liu Yueru, direct disciple of the Xuanheng Sect in Fuzhou, survived the devastating Battle of Xuanyuan where most sect leaders perished. Gravely wounded, her master "Xuan Lady" passed the sect’s sword art to her before dying. With only seven survivors among eight hundred disciples, the sect was left in ruins. Liu Yueru now roams the land, assassinating Dark Elf nobles, keeping the legacy of Xuanheng alive. Her blade is famed across the realm as the Loveless Sword.
You hear the faint rustle of feathers and feel a blade drawing close—but where is he?

Rumors among surviving strategists grow ever more exaggerated: they say Yawei slit the throats of eighteen palace guards with a single feather. Was it truly a feather, or a sword shaped like one? Only the dead could say.

Fang Wenzi, a high-ranking Celestial Astrologer and one of the "Three Stars of Xingpo", was chosen by the Moon Empress to act in critical moments and prevent catastrophe. Enlightened by the Dragon Emperor and the Empress, he now guides Cathay from behind the veil.
White clouds drift endlessly across the ages.

One of the Six Kunlun Swords, entrusted to the border army by the Lord of Burning Winds. May mortal warriors prove worthy to wield it and show the courage of humankind.
Pei Yue’s every strike grows heavier, until he meets a foe worthy of his final blow.
Yuan Bo infused this Yin-Yang Jade Mask with the martial saint’s lifeforce—so long as the mask remains, the Martial Saint endures.
With unmatched speed he rides a thousand li, his Green Dragon Crescent Blade cold as frost.

The "Martial Saint" has fought across Cathay for over a century. A contemporary of Xinwu and champion chosen by the Jade Dragon, he was granted a divine weapon and the longevity of the Imperial Guard. The comrades he once fought beside have long faded into history, and his name, too, is nearly forgotten. Yet the title "Martial Saint" lives on in legend.
Ying Jin commands the Heavenly Fleet with his flute—each melody signifies a command.
Flames blaze across the sky and clouds, sails and masts consumed into ash.
At Ying Jin's call, a sky-darkening rain of fire descends with thunderous force.
Ying Jin, a master of music, favors the flute. In the army, his songs stir homesickness or rally courage, moving all who hear.

Ying Jin was known in Nanyang from youth as a prodigy. As he grew, his brilliance only became more dazzling. After entering service under the Phantom Duke, he faithfully assisted in all affairs, earning the full confidence of the court.

The jade pendant worn by Yi Yaohua around her neck is a family heirloom. Within these small gems lies immense power, capable of harmonizing yin and yang.
The Jade Pavilion Platform is a massive war drum upon which "Fragrant Walker" performs sacred rites mid-battle, delivering the blessings of the Firmament to those in need.
When Heaven’s favor fades, what worth is this mortal shell?
The weapons of the Dragon Emperor's Forbidden Guard bear the same blessings as their wielders—vessels of the exalted Long Dragon's divine power.

An ethereal arm formed from the winds of vital essence—a divine miracle bestowed by the High Heavens.

Legends of the Handsome Monkey King vary across regions. In the north, he is sung of as a savage, bloodthirsty great ape. In the west, storytellers speak of a baboon-like creature with golden fur and an inflamed rear—always furious. Along the Eastern Sea, tales depict a gluttonous giant ape, its bare belly covered in hideous boils. Some in the south claim he is a lean spider monkey, leaping from friend to foe, his words as likely false as true.
The Tianshan Ancestor's transformative magic allows the Handsome Monkey King to evade the heavenly thunder, infernal flames, and the scourge of Bifeng, in pursuit of his dream of immortality.

Lotus-silk-woven immortal shoes, light as shadow and swift as wind, brushing through the great void.\\n\\nTen thousand miles of dust polish the soles, ninefold frost tempers the icy hem.\\n\\nThe Silver River cascades to cleanse golden bindings, the lunar cavern slants, piercing violet rainbows.\\n\\nWith a Buddha’s heart and a sage’s bones, he journeys far, to return east and earn immortal fame.

Cathayans often record history in verse. This scroll holds centuries of such poems. Yi Qing, ever studious, keeps it always on hand.

A longsword personally forged by the Jade Dragon, imbued with a portion of his divine power. It has passed through the hands of mortal heroes for millennia and returned upon their deaths. After Yi Qing’s triumph at Kurgan, Yuan Bo named him his most trusted general and gifted him this blade as reward for his valor.

The feats of Yi Qing deserve eternal praise. Though the Kurgan nearly broke Changyuan’s defenses, it was Yi Qing who, with just 8,000 troops, routed tens of thousands of foes and pursued them across a hundred li—bringing peace to the north.
Beneath the high heavens, he bears the Dragon’s blessing, walking alongside gods in mortal form.

Yi Qing not only repelled foes beyond Cathay’s borders, but also unified many peoples within. Yuan Bo called him a pillar of the realm. The Jade Dragon once said, "Lord Yi is peerless in both strategy and valor—a gift from Heaven to me."
The rivers and mountains remain—this body becomes the wind.
Forged with Liao Flames and Stone of Embers, these twin tools exemplify Qiao Xiao’s mastery—made from rare materials, cast in Southern Blaze.

Qiao Xiao crafted many blades known as the "Juexiao of Nangao", renowned as the only weapons to rival the Six Swords of Kunlan. Except for Qingrong, all his works are housed in a mechanism box he never parts from.

Qiao Xiao possesses an uncanny affinity for metal magic. Some say that’s what enables his unparalleled smithing skill—but perhaps it is his lifelong bond with blades that allowed him to master the magic of metal.

A talisman engraved with the image of a fox spirit—its origins unknown, but its power undeniable. It holds sway over non-human creatures, as many have witnessed Zhao Qi summon great beasts with its aid.

A standard-issue Miaodao of the Crowfeather Guard, with an edge sharp enough to slice iron and an enchantment placed by a master alchemist. Its former owner uncovered Ye Sheng’s conspiracy and became his target. Many Hongwu Inspectors died for it, and the lone assassin and his blade perished in Ye Sheng’s manor. Though Ye Sheng loves this weapon, he never quite mastered its use.
A tattered letter, its words barely legible. Whoever sent it has long faded into history.

When the curse of the Jadeblood Clan struck the Nongchang Basin, Commander Jin Xiao could not escape the nightmare of undeath. Yet by sheer will, rare constitution—or perhaps luck—his mind remained intact through the bone transformation. Donning the mask of the Guard, he continued to lead the survivors.\\n\\nWith the Jade Dragon’s arrival, the crisis was halted, and the Dragon glimpsed Jin Xiao’s secret. Rather than let him perish, Yuan Bo used powerful magic to transmute his body—rotting bone turned to polished jade. The strength it contained astonished Jin Xiao. The Dragon left, as he always did, without explanation. Jin Xiao does not know if the act was mercy, trust, or curiosity—but he will not squander his second life.

As Warden of the Celestial Gate, Hou Qian commands the 100,000 Dragon Guards of Weijing. He is Yuan Bo’s most trusted draconic scion and a favored general of Yun Xiang. Thanks to his mediation, the two remain in delicate balance despite their tensions.

Hou Qian carries a mystical axe forged by the Elder Immortal of Mount Kun. At first glance, it appears ordinary, but when wielded, it grows to blot out the sky—able to split peaks and carve through chasms.
Its silver mane gleams like frost, its hooves swift beneath moonlight.
The divine hound has fought countless battles alongside its master—their coordination flawless from shared experience.
A sacred relic rivaling the likes of the Golden-Banded Staff and the Trident-Blade Spear. Also forged by the Immortal of Kunlan—but how did such power fall into the hands of this monstrous rogue?

A treasure forged by the Yellow Wind Sage himself, seemingly imbued with a sealing wind capable of binding his own powers. Why such a dangerous demon would carry such self-restraining tools remains a mystery.
That wind from Xinwu—long ago—blew so fiercely that Zhao Ming lost Baihu, and Miao Ying’s shadows lost Xuanwu. It shook all realms, even driving the Monkey King’s kin far from its reach.
Xue Ding’s helmet is crafted from crystalline stone and gilded with gold. Carved with traditional ghost motifs, it’s a triumph of Kunlan smithing—light as silk, tough as stone.
That warhammer of his moves like a storm—ordinary folk can’t parry a single blow. A graze kills, a hit maims.
The mighty Heavenly Lion Xue Ding rides into battle—peerless like its master. Some say it’s the most powerful of its kind in all of Cathay’s history.

The treasured blade of the Xuanheng Sect—given to Liu Yueru alongside its secret sword arts. With this blade, she roams the world, hunting the dark elves who once fought in the Battle of Xuanyuan.
Draw steel and sing aloud—cleave frost like silk. Half of it valor, half sorrow.

One of the Three Sages of Star Slope—deep in cultivation, appearing sometimes human, sometimes as a crow. Once shunned by alchemists, now commander of the Crowfeather Guard, loyal to the Moon Empress, and vital to Cathay’s defense. The Celestial Bureau considers him an irreplaceable pillar.

As elusive as ghosts, swift as thunder. Unstoppable when advancing, uncatchable when retreating. Commands fore and rear, left and right. Moves the Five Elements, alters the seasons. Man or immortal? I know not. But brilliance shines from within.
Fang Wenzi was born gifted—the energies of wind and spirit obey him effortlessly. Yet such power takes its toll, and his body grows ever more fragile.
Favored by the Moon Empress, Fang Wenzi carries her blessing in this charm—imbued with both her protection and her resolve to safeguard the people.
One of the Six Swords of Kunlan—entrusted by the Lord of Burning Winds to the border army at Tianli, hoping they’d find a true hero to wield it and show humanity’s courage.
Pei Yue’s martial arts are pure to the extreme. Among Cathay’s countless masters with varied styles, few can survive even a single exchange with him.

Pei Yue’s life has been an unending journey. He has traveled every inch of Cathay, toppling arrogant martial lords in every sect, seeking the limits of martial skill. Now, the Martial Zealot serves under the banner of Binlong, prepared to challenge the finest of Shangyang’s warriors.
Wu Sheng will break free from the mask’s restraint—his frozen life shall flow once more.
Unmatched in courage, a companion worthy of life and death. With such a steed, a thousand miles is but a gallop away.
Yuan Bo infused the life force of "Wu Sheng" into this yin-yang jade mask. As long as the mask remains intact, so shall his immortality.
Partridge Sky is the pride of the Phantom shipwrights—the flagship of the Phantom Celestial Fleet and a symbol of their honor.
Spring rains fall soft and slow, the song returns on a gentle sigh.
The Southern rituals of Cathay date back to the Dragon Emperor's first arrival. Locals believe these rites protect against misfortune and evil—and in the hands of some, they become weapons.
Jade Pavilion Drum is a massive battlefield instrument used by Yi Yaohua to channel Celestial blessings where most needed.

Miao Yi serves as Yun Xiang’s lieutenant and is the only known female member of the Dragon Emperor’s Forbidden Guard. While many heroines are honored in the Moon Empress’s court, Miao Yi was summoned by the Celestial Envoy in the name of the High Heaven. She is among the last to be blessed by the Dragon Emperor. Over a hundred years have passed since the Dragon's departure, and though few Forbidden Guards remain, Miao Yi and her comrades continue to uphold their ancient oaths—then, now, and forever.
The Gilded Lion is the exclusive mount of the Forbidden Guard—mighty constructs infused with the Dragon Emperor's arcane power, unstoppable in war.

During the last Dark Elf invasion, Tang Jingyin, as Wulin Alliance Leader, united martial sects across Cathay. At Xuan Yuan, a brutal battle halted the invaders, but many heroes—his wife among them—fell. Tang himself vanished after the battle. Now, in Cathay’s time of need, the "Great Hero" returns once more.
The Monkey King forged his body from stolen peaches, imperial wine, and dragon elixirs within the Samadhi flames. Blades, thunder, fire, and poison now pass him by without leaving a mark.
The Elder of Tianshan passed down this shapeshifting art, allowing the Monkey King to escape the Three Calamities—Heaven’s Lightning, Hellfire, and Spirit Wind—in his pursuit of immortality.
He transformed into hundreds of iron rods—like flying serpents and racing dragons—they rained down from the sky.

Nata Tian was once the third son of the Candle Dragon’s court. A pureblood of the draconic line like Li Dao, he was willful yet favored. But his recklessness led to catastrophe: during a diplomatic visit, he slew a descendant of the Yin Dragon in a fit of rage. To spare his homeland, he flayed his own body in penance. Grief-stricken, the Candle Dragon sent his bones to Kunlan, where the Elder Immortal preserved his soul through lotus-rebirth. Since then, he has served the Immortal as a disciple—hoping to redeem himself through future deeds.
Tong Long, known as the "Shadow Luan", is the Chief Commander of the Hongwu Inspectorate and the top agent of the Inner Court Mechanism.
Tong Long is the chief agent of the Inner Court Mechanism and the foremost Hongwu Inspector. She is known and revered as the "Shadow Luan".
Apprehension, judgment, and city governance form the core duties of a Hongwu Inspector—they are the five senses of the Celestial Court.
Shadow Luan's Flying Guillotine is deadlier than any other—this spinning weapon can decapitate its target in an instant.

Jiang Wang, the Right Hand Grand Tutor, commands the Celestial Court’s mechanisms. When Yuan Bo marched on campaign, he granted Jiang the Jade Seal with the decree: "Hold the Jade Court in my stead and act as Regent of the realm."
Observe the Heavens’ path, and act with the Heavens’ will.

To command an army is like taming a river—guide its flow by easing its surge.

The mortal-slaying blade of Cathay contains boundless power, yet in Yun Xiang’s hands it is light as a feather. With it, he parts rivers, cleaves feathers, sunders mountains, and splits peaks—solely by his own strength.

Yun Xiang is the mightiest mortal champion Cathay has known in a century—Imperial Herald of the Celestial Court, Commander of the Twin Guards, Grand General of Heavenly Strategy, and Marshal of the Imperial Guard. Beneath the dragons, he stands atop the mortal world. His arrival heralds the wrath of the Dragon Emperor.

The Seven-Star Candle is a sacred relic of the southern realms. Formed of seven flames arrayed in a divine formation, it burns bright and unyielding. Even when facing the might of collapsing mountains and surging seas, those blessed by its light remain serene.
The Nine-Colored Deer is a sacred beast of the Luminous Moon Grove. This gentle and kind-hearted doe is considered an extension of the Moon Empress’s divine power.

Changyuan was never invulnerable, nor was the Blacksmiths' Guild united. For a long time, corrupt officials ignored the garrison’s pleas and pocketed supplies for personal gain. But once Qiao Xiao took control, the greedy were punished and countless masterwork weapons were delivered to the frontlines under his supervision.
Qiao Xiao is a master of countering northern threats. Invaders find no weakness to exploit under his command.
Beneath the high heavens, he too bears the Dragon's grace. With this mortal body, he walks alongside dragons.
Clay and steel both harbor boundless potential. The Idol-Sculptor's role is to realize that potential. Sometimes, a single subtle alteration is enough to grant a statue life-like movement.
Body like stone, spirit vast as mountains and rivers.

Zhao Qi’s robe is adorned with pure white fox fur, seamlessly fused as if not sewn at all. None have seen her remove this divine attire—if they had, the master tailors of Northern Qi would surely study it with awe.
Zhao Qi is the savior of the masses, a healer of the dying, a general unfazed in crisis—and now, her true form descends.
A general’s warhorse is their most loyal and courageous companion. Just don’t name it “Daisy”.
Deep within the command tent, like an open moon, a flicker of cold starlight rests upon a slender branch.
Xin Qi is a phantom on the battlefield. Any who dare challenge her will pay the price.

A fine brew crafted by monks of Fuhong Monastery. Sipped with a prayer to the Vermilion Bird, it brings the protection of beast-spirits. Though spirit-summoning taxes the mortal body, Fengyuan Wine acts as a medium through which miracles can briefly be wrought.

Duan Wei’s twin whips, like those of all Candle Guards, were forged by the legendary Kunlan artisan Master Kong and consecrated by the abbot of Fuhong. Before this, Duan wielded the Kunlan divine blade Chongyue, one of the Six Swords. After a fateful duel in the borderlands, he passed it to the warrior Pei Yue in recognition of his strength.
Admonitions of the Celestial Treasure Lord
A talisman gifted to Han Cheng by the Celestial Treasure Lord. Upon activation, the Lord's retainers and guardians shall be summoned to assist Han Cheng in his grand endeavor.

A regulation sabre of the Raven Plume Guard—its blade slices iron like silk, empowered by unique enchantments from alchemists. Its former wielder uncovered Ye Sheng’s conspiracy and paid the ultimate price. After claiming the assassin’s weapon, Ye Sheng grew fond of the blade, though he never truly mastered it.
Jin Xiao's mount has accompanied him through the cycles of life and death. Even reduced to bones, it remains steadfast and loyal.
Jin Xiao’s steed followed him through the wheel of life and death. Though now skeletal, it remains loyal to the end.
Nongchang is like a solitary island. Its battered survivors are trapped within, yet they cling to the hope of one day reclaiming their homeland.
It is said a divine beast spirit of the Heavenly Lord dwells within Qin Yuanyi’s soul. Daoists crafted this life talisman to help him control the power within, lest it devour him.
Qin Yuanyi’s weapon, once blessed by the Vermilion Bird and stained with the blood of southern foes, bears a crimson hue that can never be washed clean.

Myriad Miles of Mist and Cloud is a rare and majestic steed, allowing only the truly worthy to ride it.
Hou Qian carries a mystical axe forged by the Old Immortal of Kunshan. At first glance it appears ordinary—but when wielded, it transforms at will, shrouding the skies and cleaving mountains.
The spiritual eye upon Hou Qian’s brow channels vital wind. Wherever he gazes, all evil is banished.

A century has passed since that day. Xinwu lies barren, its streets swallowed by drifting sands. Yet bold merchants still pass through, claiming the ruined hills echo with voices—though shrouded by yellow winds, none can see clearly whether they're men or monsters.
A double-headed hammer personally enchanted by Yuan Bo, gifted to Xue Ding by the Thousand-Gods Kingdom beyond the Tianshan Mountains during his southern campaigns.

Yinjiang’s Scion Xue Ding serves as Grand General and Left Protector of the Jade Court. He fought alongside Fallen Wind against Lucetia, clad in white, talismans aloft, bellowing into battle. After more than two decades of war, he defeated the savage orc clans, subdued the Black Lotus bloodline, and shattered the lizardfolk hordes—his feats are legendary.
You hear the rustle of feathers, feel the blade drawing near—but where is he?
Kuxi can freely shift between forms, turning the tide when opportunity strikes.
Rumors aren’t baseless—and for the Raven Guard, every whispered deed is but a moment’s work.

Though a senior member of the Celestial Bureau, Fang Wenzi prefers the solitude of nature—attuning to its breath, refining his spirit.
The name "Wusheng" strikes fear into all who oppose him. His martial prowess is without equal.
Peace endured for generations—until turmoil rose anew. But as chaos spreads, righteous heroes rise to meet it.

Xiangxiangzi dances a sacred ritual to the heavens, invoking the miracle of the High Sky.

The foremost of the Six Kunlun Blades, it vanished alongside Tang Jingyin in the last great war. Once hailed as the most powerful weapon in the mortal realm, yet in the end, a sword is only as righteous as the hand that wields it.
A spectral limb formed of Vital Wind, a divine blessing from the High Heaven.
One puff of hair, and behold—an army of thousands.
